newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate edges up 10 bps to 7.6 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate edges up 10 bps to 7.6 pct.

text.p: The Croatian average lending rate edged up 10 basis points to 7.6 percent on Tuesday due to higher rates on some of the interbank kuna loans.
Dealers said higher deposits at commercial banks boosted supply of kuna funds to 115 million and halved demand.
Settlements shrank to 22 million kuna, of which 16.1 million accounted for fresh loans.
Interbank borrowing was mostly flat at 8.0 percent, pushing the five-10 day rate to 7.5 from 7.0 percent. Insurers' 10-15 day loans were unchanged at 7.0 percent.

Overnight trade totalled 68.6 million kuna after two banks bought 65 million to maintain their reserve payment. The rest was granted to two banks with shortfalls, leaving 388 million on the supply side.

The central bank said it did not sell or buy hard currency. Its kuna midrates for Wednesday slightly eased to 5.3478 against the dollar and to 3.5576 versus the German mark. -- Laura Lui, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
